skills.name: Convert terminating decimals greater than 1 to fractions
Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer
Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction
Divide proper fractions in the form: Integer ÷ Fraction
Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers

explanations.A: In the diagram we have 8 lots of a 1/2, this is the same as writing 8 ✕ 1/2. Two halves make one whole, therefore eight halves make four wholes. Therefore 8 ✕ 1/2 = 4.
explanations.B: Not quite, I think you did 8 x 2. How many halves do you need to make one whole? If you have 8 halves how many wholes will you have?
explanations.C: Not quite, I think you did 4 x 2. There are more than four halves in the diagram. How many are there? What do you get if you join two of the halves together? How many wholes will there be in total?
explanations.D: Not quite. How many halves do you need to make one whole? If you have 8 halves how many wholes will you have?

explanations.A: Not quite. How many thirds do you need to make one whole? If you have 12 thirds how many wholes will you have?
explanations.B: Not quite, I think you multiplied by 3 rather than a third. How many thirds do you need to make one whole? If you have 12 thirds how many wholes will you have?
explanations.C: Not quite, I think you multiplied 4 by 3. There are more than four thirds in the diagram. How many are there? What do you get if you join three of the thirds together? How many wholes will there be in total?
explanations.D: In the diagram we have 12 lots of a 1/3, this is the same as writing 12 ✕ 1/3. Three thirds make one whole, therefore twelve thirds make four wholes. Therefore 12 ✕ 1/3 = 4.

explanations.A: Not quite. What happens when you multiply by decimals or fractions? Try these calculations to see: 8 ✕ 0.5 and 8 ✕ 1/2.
explanations.B: Not quite. What happens when you divide by decimals or fractions? Try these calculations to see: 8 ÷ 0.5 and 4 ÷ (1/3).
explanations.C: Not quite. What happens when you multiply or divide by decimals or fractions? Try these calculations to see: 8 ✕ 0.5, 8 ÷ 0.5 and 8 ÷ (1/3).
explanations.D: Both Tom and Katie's statements are correct when we look at multiplying and dividing whole numbers. BUT both statements are incorrect when we start to look at multiplying and dividing by decimals and fractions. For example: 8 ✕ 0.5 = 4 and 8 ÷ 0.5 = 16

explanations.A: Not quite. Use a calculator to explore what happens when we multiply and divide by fractions. What is 8 ÷ (1/2)?
explanations.B: Not quite. Use a calculator to explore what happens when we multiply and divide by fractions. What is 8 ✕ (1/2)?
explanations.C: Multiplying a positive whole number by a fraction less than one makes the original number decrease, for example 6 ✕ 1/3 = 1/3 + 1/3 + 1/3 + 1/3 + 1/3 + 1/3 = 2, therefore Tom is correct. Dividing a positive whole number by a fraction less than one makes the original number increase, for example 4 ÷ (1/2) = 8, as there are 8 halves in 4 wholes, therefore Katie is correct.
explanations.D: Not quite. Use a calculator to explore what happens when we multiply and divide by fractions. What is 8 ÷ (1/2)? What is 8 ✕ (1/2)?

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you multiplied the 2 by 3 rather than cubing it. Remember (2/3)³ = 2/3 ✕ 2/3 ✕ 2/3.
explanations.B: Be careful. Remember we must always use the order of operations (BIDMAS). What comes first the indices (the power) or the multiplication?
explanations.C: Not quite. Check both these statements again. Remember we must always apply the order of operations (BIDMAS) in the correct order.
explanations.D: Tom is incorrect because (2/3)³ = 2/3 ✕ 2/3 ✕ 2/3 = 8/27 NOT 6/9 and Katie is incorrect because she has not followed the order of operations. (2/3)³ should be calculated before multiplying by 1/4.

explanations.A: Applying the order of operations to this calculation we must calculate (1/3)³ before multiplying by 1/4. Jo started this question by correctly calculating the value of (1/3)³, therefore she is correct. Paul started by multiplying 1/4 and 1/3, which is incorrect.
explanations.B: Be careful. Remember we must always use the order of operations (BIDMAS). What comes first the indices (the power) or the multiplication?
explanations.C: Not quite. Be careful. Remember we must always use the order of operations (BIDMAS). What comes first the indices (the power) or the multiplication?
explanations.D: Not quite, at least one of them is correct. Remember we must always use the order of operations (BIDMAS). What comes first the indices (the power) or the multiplication?

explanations.A: Not quite. I think you have just replaced the decimal point with a fraction line. To turn these decimals into fractions try writing them as whole numbers over ten and then simplifying.
explanations.B: Not quite. 0.2 is not equal to 1/2 and 0.5 is not equal to 1/5. To turn these decimals into fractions try writing them as whole numbers over ten and then simplifying.
explanations.C: Not quite. Both 5/6 and 2/5 are proper fractions which means they have a value of less than one NOT more than one. To turn these decimals into fractions try writing them as whole numbers over ten and then simplifying.

explanations.A: Not quite. I think you have just replaced the decimal point with a fraction line. To turn these decimals into fractions try writing them as whole numbers over ten and then simplifying.
explanations.C: Not quite. Both 5/12 and 5/16 are proper fractions which means they have a value of less than one NOT more than one. To turn these decimals into fractions try writing them as whole numbers over ten and then simplifying.
explanations.D: Not quite. 0.4 is not equal to 1/4 and 0.2 is not equal to 1/2. To turn these decimals into fractions try writing them as whole numbers over ten and then simplifying.

explanations.A: Not quite. This would be the area of the triangle if each square was 1 cm by 1 cm NOT 1/4 cm by 1/4 cm. To find the area first find the length of the base and perpendicular height. If the base is 3 squares how many cm would this be?
explanations.B: If each square is 1/4 cm by 1/4 cm then this triangle has a base of 3/4 cm and a perpendicular height of 2/4 (1/2) cm. The area of a triangle is found by multiplying the base and the perpendicular height and then dividing by 2. 3/4 ✕ 1/2 = 3/8. 3/8 ÷ 2 = 3/8 ✕ 1/2 = 3/16. Therefore the area of the triangle is 3/16 cm².
explanations.C: Not quite, this is the base of the triangle. Remember the area of a triangle is base multiplied by perpendicular height divided by 2. What would the base and perpendicular height be if each square is 1/4 cm by 1/4 cm?
explanations.D: So close! Remember the area of a triangle is base multiplied by the perpendicular height divided by 2.

explanations.A: So close! Remember the area of a triangle is base multiplied by the perpendicular height divided by 2.
explanations.B: Not quite. Remember the area of a triangle is base multiplied by perpendicular height divided by 2. What would the base and perpendicular height be if each square is 1/5 cm by 1/5 cm?
explanations.C: If each square is 1/5 cm by 1/5 cm then this triangle has a base of 3/5 cm and a perpendicular height of 4/5 cm. The area of a triangle is found by multiplying the base and the perpendicular height and then dividing by 2. 3/5 ✕ 4/5 = 12/25. 12/25 ÷ 2 = 12/25 ✕ 1/2 = 12/50 = 6/25. Therefore the area of the triangle is 6/25 cm².
explanations.D: Not quite. This would be the area of the triangle if each square was 1 cm by 1 cm NOT 1/5 cm by 1/5 cm. To find the area first find the length of the base and perpendicular height. If the base is 3 squares how many cm would this be?
